hawaiian_text: Ho'ouna maila 'o 'Ama'u ke ali'i mai Waikīkī mai, 'ehā po'e kaua, aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui, pēlā ā pau nā po'e 'ehā. A hiki lākou ma ke kula o Keahumoa, komo lākou ā loko o ka hale, 'a'ohe kanaka. A mākaukau lākou e ho'i, kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku. A lohe lākou i ka leo, 'a'ohe na'e he 'ike 'ia o ke kino, nīnau aku lākou: "'Auhea 'oe e wala'au nei?" 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Eia nō wau i luna nei." Pi'i a'ela 'ewalu kānaka, 'ehā ma ke kua o ka hale, 'ehā ma ke alo o ka hale ā loa'a 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o. 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" 'Ī aku lākou: "I hele mai nei mākou e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o, he wahi keiki 'u'uku e like me 'oe, he ikaika a me ke koa loa, nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i."
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: At that time, 'Ama'u, the chief from Waikīkī, was a strong man, and there were two warriors. There was a large person's strength among the individuals, like all the others. They went to the plains of Keahumoa, entered the house, and there was no one there. Suddenly, they returned, and Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from the top of the fire. They heard the voice, no one had knowledge of the head, and they asked: "How are you going to do this?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "This is what I will do." He took a person's shadow, two at the door of the house, two at the side of the house and the top. Nāmakaokapāo'o asked: "What is this that you are doing?" They replied: "We are going to live with Nāmakaokapāo'o, a place for the children of 'u'uku to be like you, a strong and brave man, he alone was the son of his father, Puali'i."
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>  
At that time, 'Ama'u, the chief from Waikīkī, was a strong man, and there were two warriors. There was a large person's strength among the individuals, like all the others. They went to the plains of Keahumoa, entered the house, and there was no one there. Suddenly, they returned, and Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from the top of the fire. They heard the voice, no one had knowledge of the head, and they asked: "How are you going to do this?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "This is what I will do." He took a person's shadow, two at the door of the house, two at the side of the house and the top. Nāmakaokapāo'o asked: "What is this that you are doing?" They replied: "We are going to live with Nāmakaokapāo'o, a place for the children of 'u'uku to be like you, a strong and brave man, he alone was the son of his father, Puali'i."  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
**Paragraph 12:**  
• The passage continues the narrative of Nāmakaokapāo'o’s defiance of 'Ai Kapu traditions, introducing new characters and symbolic actions;  
• **'Ama'u** (a name meaning "to fall" or "to descend," possibly referencing a lineage or descent from a sacred place) is identified as a **ke ali'i** (chief) from **Waikīkī**, emphasizing his noble status; **"ehā po'e kaua"** (two strong men) likely refers to warriors or figures of power, contrasting with Nāmakaokapāo'o’s earlier destructive behavior;  
• **"Aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui"** (There was a large person's strength among the individuals) suggests a cultural emphasis on physical prowess and the sacredness of strength, a value tied to the **'Ai Kapu era** (sacred dietary laws), where strength was often linked to ritual and social hierarchy;  
• **"Ke kula o Keahumoa"** (the plains of Keahumoa) is a recurring location in the story, symbolizing a space of conflict or transformation, possibly tied to the **'Ai Kapu** practice of communal living and resource management;  
• **"Kā 'oukou o 'one'i"** (you of the head) may allude to the **"po'o" (head)** as a metaphor for authority or sacrifice, echoing earlier references to **"po'o"** in Nāmakaokapāo'o’s name (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1986:369) *po'o*: "head, chief, first, beginning"; *kaua* (strong) and *kānaka* (person) combine to imply a focus on leadership and power dynamics;  
• The **"kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku"** (Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from the top of the fire) symbolizes a confrontation with the sacred fire of the **'Ai Kapu** system, where fire was both a ritual and a metaphor for divine authority;  
• The dialogue "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" ("What is this that you are doing?") reflects the tension between traditional practices and Nāmakaokapāo'o’s radical actions, as seen in earlier paragraphs where he dismantled sacred structures;  
• The mention of **"wahi keiki 'u'uku"** (place for the children of 'u'uku, a type of fish) ties to the **'Ai Kapu** symbolism of substituting fish for human sacrifice, as noted in previous examples (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1986:369) *ulua* (fish) as a substitute for human offerings); **"u'uku"** here may represent a sacred or communal resource, contrasting with Nāmakaokapāo'o’s earlier destruction of sweet potato patches;  
• **"He ikaika a me ke koa loa"** (strong and brave) reinforces Nāmakaokapāo'o’s characterization as a figure of defiance, akin to the **"koako" (warrior)** in Hawaiian lore, challenging the status quo of the **'Ai Kapu** era;  
• The phrase **"nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i"** (he alone was the son of his father, Puali'i) highlights the **lineage of Puali'i** (a name associated with divine or ancestral connections), suggesting a continuation of the conflict between Nāmakaokapāo'o and the traditional power structures of the time.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Chief 'Ama'u sent four regiments of soldiers from Waikīkī totalling forty-eight men. When they reached the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was there. When they were ready to return back to Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from on top of the roof. They heard the voice, but didn't see any body, and they asked, "Where is that voice coming from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four men went onto the roof and four on the face of the house and got a hold of Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "What in the world are you all doing here?" They said, "We came to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who is really strong and brave. He killed his father, Puali'i."
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
